raw_text:
Tory leader quits legal position
 
 David McLetchie has resigned from his post as a partner in a legal firm following criticism over his dual role.
 
 The Scottish Conservative leader had insisted that his legal work with Tods Murray did not influence the causes he supports. But on Friday he said: "I have tendered my resignation as a partner with immediate effect." Mr McLetchie had received advice from Holyrood officials about what details he needed to declare. Labour said he had "cleverly" not asked about paid advocacy. A Tory spokesman "totally refuted" any wrongdoing.
 
 Mr McLetchie received advice from the clerk to the standards committee after concern over him signing a parliamentary motion questioning expansion plans for Edinburgh Airport. The MSP had been a partner for Tods Murray which has a client opposing the development. Mr McLetchie did not have a complaint made against him, but when concerns were raised he sought guidance from the standards committee to clarify his position. He was advised to exercise judgement to avoid the perception of a conflict and said he had done nothing wrong.
 
 Explaining his reason for quitting the post, Mr McLetchie said: "I have been greatly concerned by the recent publicity surrounding my association with Tods Murray. "However, I have no wish to see a similar situation arise again. "To avoid any misconceptions in the future and be mindful of the good name of Tods Murray and the confidentiality to which its clients are entitled, I have brought forward the date of my retirement from the firm which would otherwise have happened later this year. "I am proud to have been a part of Tods Murray for the last 29 years and wish it well in the future."
 
 Labour MSP Christine May had said Mr McLetchie was "very clever" to ask the clerk to consider his conduct in respect of section 5 of the code. "He was almost bound to get the answer he wanted from this enquiry since he stands accused of breaching section 6, the section on paid advocacy," she said. Section 5 of the members interest order legally obliges MSPs to declare registrable interests before taking part in related parliamentary proceedings "where the interest would prejudice or give the appearance of prejudicing their ability to participate in a disinterested manner". However, MSPs' Code of Conduct "recognises a wider definition" of parliamentary proceedings, including a non-statutory requirement to make a declaration in relation to written notices, such as motions.
 
 But a letter from Holyrood's Chamber Office chief Ken Hughes also made clear that Mr McLetchie did not need to list any of the clients for whom he worked as a solicitor. Commenting on Mr McLetchie's decision to stand down, a Scottish Labour Party spokesman said: "This should mean Mr McLetchie doesn't breach the paid advocacy rules in future. "However it doesn't change the fact that there should be a full investigation into whether he has done this in the past."
 
 Scottish National Party Holyrood leader Nicola Sturgeon accused Mr McLetchie of failing to properly serve his constituents. Ms Sturgeon said: "I think this whole episode has been very damaging for Mr McLetchie and I'm sure he will be reflecting on it." She added that she thought that the Tories were an irrelevant party so she would not "lose any sleep over it". Peter Misselbrook, executive partner of Tods Murray said Mr McLetchie had been considering retirement later in the year. He added: "David has decided that this announcement should be made now and we fully understand and appreciate his reasons for doing so."
llama3.2:1b: Tory leader David McLetchie has resigned as a partner in law firm Tods Murray, citing concerns over criticism surrounding his dual role and seeking clarity on his position.
He had received advice from the standards committee about disclosing clients opposing Edinburgh Airport expansion plans, but did not have a complaint made against him.
McLetchie said he was "very clever" to seek guidance to avoid a conflict of interest.
llama3.2:3b: Tory leader David McLetchie has resigned as a partner at law firm Tods Murray amid criticism over his dual role, citing a need to avoid any misconceptions about his association with the firm.
gemma2:2b: David McLetchie resigned as a partner at Tods Murray legal firm after receiving criticism over his dual roles.
He had previously sought advice from Holyrood officials about his parliamentary motion signing, which involved a client opposing an Edinburgh Airport expansion plan.
Despite being advised to exercise judgment and avoid any perception of conflict, McLetchie decided to resign early to ensure no future misunderstandings.
His decision was met with varying reactions.
Labour MSPs criticized McLetchie's actions while the Scottish Labour Party spokesman felt this should prevent future breaches of paid advocacy rules.
SNP Holyrood leader Nicola Sturgeon deemed McLetchie's conduct as damaging and questioned his commitment to serving constituents, although she did not express concern about the party itself.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A Scottish Conservative leader resigned from his position as a partner in a legal firm due to dual responsibilities, having received advice from Holyrood officials about the clarification of his role.
Mr McLetchie said he had not engaged in paid advocacy and was "cleverly" not asking about it.
A Labour member of Parliament criticized him for questioning an airport expansion project, but he declined to take any action.
The Scottish National Party spokesperson accused Mr McLetchie of failing to properly serve his constituents.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tory leader David McLetchie resigns from legal firm after admitting dual role, sparking controversy over paid advocacy.
qwen2.5:3b: Scottish Conservative leader David McLetchie quit his position as a partner at legal firm Tods Murray after facing criticism over his dual role, including signing a parliamentary motion questioning airport expansion plans.
McLetchie received advice from Holyrood officials about what to declare and did not ask them about paid advocacy.
He resigned due to concerns over potential conflicts of interest and to avoid future misconceptions.

Labour MSP Christine May accused McLetchie of cleverly seeking guidance for his conduct, while the Scottish Labour Party spokesman stated that this does not change the need for a full investigation into past violations.

The SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon criticized McLetchie's service to constituents and did not expect him to be relevant in politics, but Tods Murray executive partner Peter Misselbrook supported McLetchie's decision.

 David McLetchie has resigned from his post as a partner in a legal firm following criticism over his dual role.
The Conservative leader insisted on his legal work with Tods Murray not influencing the causes he supports.

To avoid any misconceptions in the future and be mindful of the good name of Tods Murray and the confidentiality to which its clients are entitled, I have brought forward the date of my retirement from the firm which would otherwise have happened later this year.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: David McLetchie resigned from his legal firm as a partner following criticism over his dual role.

tinyllama:1.1b: The article discusses the resignation of David McLetchi from the legal position at a Scottish Conservative party firm following criticism over his dual role as a partner.

The Scottish Conservative leader, David McLetchi, has tendered his resignation as a partner with immediate effect after receiving advice from Holyrood officials that he should declare his interests in relation to an upcoming parliamentary motion related to Edinburgh Airport.

The MSPI has refuted any wrongdoing, and the Scottish National Party (SNP) speakerman criticized Mr McLetchi's decision to stand down, stating that the MP should not breach rules on paid advocacy due to his previous work as a solicitor.
The SNP leader, Nicola Stuart-Grove, suggested that Mr McLetchi had failed to properly serve his constituents and vowed never to lose sleep over it.
The Scottish National Party's Holyrood leader, Nicola Sturowsky, also commented on the matter, stating that she would not "lose any sleep" over Mr McLetchie's resignation.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The resignation of Tory party leader David McLetchie, who was a partner in a legal firm, has been announced by Holyrood officials following allegations of him being involved with clients who supported certain causes.
McLetchie was tendering his resignation as a partner with immediate effect and stated that he had asked for clarification on the issue regarding paid advocacy.
The Tory party has dismissed any wrongdoing and claims that McLetchie made a mistake about signing parliamentary motions.
However, Holyrood officials have advised him not to reveal his clients in order to avoid any misconceptions.
McLetchie has been accused of breaching section 5 of the members interest order, which requires MSPs to declare their interests before participating in related parliamentary proceedings.

Labour party MSP Christine May claims that McLetchie is clever for asking for clarification on the issue of paid advocacy, especially since it would have been against the code's section 6 regulations, which stipulates that MSPs should not prejudice their participation in disinterested affairs.
phi:2.7b: David McLetchie, a Scottish Conservative leader and former legal partner at Tods Murray, has resigned from both roles following criticism over his dual role.
He had defended his work with the law firm but stated he had received advice from Holyrood officials on what to disclose.

A Labour MP accused him of cleverly not asking about paid advocacy, while a Tory spokesman rejected any wrongdoing and said that Mr McLetchie did not ask questions about his conflict of interest in relation to a parliamentary motion.
The MSP who made the comments has since expressed support for Mr McLetchie's decision to resign from his legal role.

McLetchie received advice from Holyrood officials about what details to declare and explained his reason for quitting the post, stating that he wanted to avoid any future misconceptions and maintain Tods Murray's confidentiality.
Although he did not breach paid advocacy rules in this instance, some argue there should be a full investigation into whether he has done so in the past.
